newsitem.title: CANADA: Philip Environmental, BASF in deal.
newsitem.headline: Philip Environmental, BASF in deal.

text.p: Philip Environmental Inc and BASF AG's polymers division said Philip Environmental has become the North American operating partner for BASF's proprietary polyurethane recycling technology.
BASF and Philip will construct a 10 million pounds-per-year recycling facility at Philip's existing operations in Detroit, the firms said in a joint statement.
The facility, which will be operated by Philip, will be on-line by the first quarter of 1997. Philip will collect, process and chemically recycle polyurethane waste into recyclate polyols.
Rigid thermoset polyurethane plastic is chemically transformed into its basic chemical building blocks, polyols, for reuse in new polyurethane parts, the companies said on Tuesday.
Polyurethane is widely used in the production of automotive parts such as bumpers, mouldings and structural components.
Recycled polyols will be marketed by BASF, primarily to automotive parts manufacturers, and will be competitively priced with virgin polyols.
